H0.text: A virus is the kind of agent Dr. Wagner is studying, because she discovers that one of its structures is double‑stranded RNA.

H1.text: A protist is the newly discovered, disease‑causing agent that Dr. Wagner is studying, because she determined that one of its structures is double‑stranded RNA.

H2.text: A fungus is the kind of disease-causing agent Dr. Wagner is studying, which she determined to contain double‑stranded RNA.

H3.text: A bacterium is the kind of agent Dr. Wagner is studying, because she discovered that one of its structures is double‑stranded RNA.

A4.text: Rotaviruses, known globally as a common cause of gastroenteritis in young children, are dsRNA viruses.

A5.text: Since cells do not produce double‑stranded RNA during normal nucleic acid metabolism, natural selection has favored the evolution of enzymes that destroy dsRNA on contact.
